qas.question: Who re-translated the Reflections into French?
Which British ministers disagreed with Burke's Reflections?

answers.text: Richard Sheridan and Charles James Fox

qas.question: What political party was Charles James Fox?
What political party was Earl Fitzwilliam?
What political party was Richard Sheridan?
What did Charles James Fox translate?

plausible_answers.text: Duke of Portland and Earl Fitzwilliam

qas.question: Who was the Duke of Portland?
When did John Cavendish write to Burke?
Who did the Duke of Devonshire recommend Reflections to?

context: <a0_0>Louis XVI<a0_0/> translated the <b5_0>Reflections<b5_0/> "from end to end" into French. Fellow <a2_0><a4_0>Whig<a4_0/><a2_0/> MPs <a1_0>Richard Sheridan and Charles James Fox<a1_0/>, disagreed with Burke and split with him. Fox thought the Reflections to be "in very bad taste" and "favouring Tory principles". Other <a3_0>Whigs<a3_0/> such as the <b6_0>Duke of Portland and Earl <b7_0>Fitzwilliam<b7_0/><b6_0/> privately agreed with Burke, but did not wish for a public breach with their Whig colleagues. Burke wrote on <b8_0>29 November 1790<b8_0/>: "I have received from the Duke of Portland, Lord Fitzwilliam, the Duke of Devonshire, Lord John Cavendish, Montagu (Frederick Montagu MP), and a long et cetera of the old Stamina of the Whiggs a most full approbation of the principles of that work and a kind indulgence to the execution". The Duke of Portland said in 1791 that when anyone criticised the Reflections to him, he informed them that he had recommended the book to <b9_0>his sons<b9_0/> as containing the true Whig creed.
